SUBJ_0002_5_to_10_years_patient_speech_p.text: That one line made my life miserable for quite a period of time. It also was very interesting because it sets some interesting dialogues around the country about whether or not people who were fully committed to equal opportunity by virtue of the fact that they were committed were biased and could not make those decisions.

And in that particular office we had all of these uh issues, the data on what companies were doing under the President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity. But it had never been used. They were just stacked in the room. But they were a a marvelous resource to give us an idea of what was where the problems were. So that was the first issue that we had were not ready to do this. The second issue was because we had no staff, we had to borrow staff. And we borrowed from every source. I had already sort of taken everybody in my offices in California back with me to the EEOC because I always thought that you needed to have somebody watching your back in Washington, D.C. And I brought the people that I thought would not only be loyal but would be capable of handling some of these issues. The second thing was that we had to deal with how do we deal with people who are not even interested in the question of sex discrimination. When we came in to be appointed, we got a very big briefing book and it was probably about this high and it had all the precedents that have been set on to uh on equal employment opportunity law. And then when it got down to the place where it said sex discrimination, there were maybe three pages.

who spent a lot of time not only castigating the Congress on this issue, but when we got in as the EEOC castigating the Commission on some of its decisions that were reached during that period of time. So we had a commission that was not experienced, that came with a very weak law, that had very little time to get going, and that on the very first day that it became operative where we were actually going to take complaints, we started with a backlog. We started with a backlog of over 3,000 cases that were delivered to us immediately. We brought people from the state and the state agencies to come in and help us. We brought people from the Justice Department to come in and help us. And little by little we were able to move forward. We finally got an office. We were able to get space in which we could then function, and then we had a chance to look at the law and decide what is it that we're going to do. We were fortunate as I said that we had a lot of experience on the issue of equal employment opportunity on the other subjects except on on sex. So there was a lot of precedence set and we used that. We each also had to take assignments. If you read the law, you will find that there is really no role for the other four commissioners. The only person who is uh who is identified as having a role with the EEOC is the chair. So the other four commissioners are not represented at all in terms of what they're supposed to do. So when we came in, because we had no staff, we had to act as both staff and commissioners.

And so what they said was, well, we will ask for a BFOQ. And they came and they asked for a BFOQ, and the EEOC had to hold hearings before they could give a BFOQ. So we held hearings on the airline situation. And we held those hearings over several days and the airlines had the biggest lawyers in the world coming in to tell us why they thought uh being a flight attendant in those days, being a stewardess, was a BFOQ. You would not believe those arguments. Today you would laugh at them.

then you could do something about challenging the discrimination. But you could not touch it if it was simply a protective law. You could not extend all of the state protective laws to women uh for women, to men as well, which was our original approach, was we thought we could just extend those laws to men and would be fine. But obviously that wouldn't work because there would be jobs that nobody could do under those circumstances. Um one of the big laws was this weightlifting law.

Uh this was not a national law, as I said, it was a state law, so it varied from state to state. In some states there were absolutely no laws on that basis. So the assumption was women could do anything they wanted or lift anything. Uh what I discovered while we were working on the state protective laws for women was essentially that they don't mind women lifting anything as long as they don't get paid for it.

So if you were if you were at home and you were lifting your children and if you were taking the groceries upstairs, that's okay. But if you were in a job which required that you lift some kind of weight, then immediately came into question whether we were too fragile to do that. And uh people like Lorena, for example, who came in over the issue of the weightlifting, lifting a particular uh amount of weight on a particular job, challenged those laws very effectively because they became very stupid. We knew that women could lift the law those packages and do those things, so why were they being discriminated against? And in many cases they were being discriminated against because those jobs that they couldn't get into were the higher paid jobs.

SUBJ_0002_5_years_patient_speech_part_00.text: Our family turned out to be the only African American family in the community. At one point in time, they were passing a petition around to get our family out of there because they didn't want black people to be in the neighborhood.

My mother took me by the hand and walked me over to the house of the man who had started the petition, and she gave him a lecture. about our family and why we were there and all the rest and then certain simply turned and went out. And so I learned something that day, although I was very little at that stage.

I arrive at my first political science class. The teacher looks down at me and then he says, if you are not prepared to do all of the work that we're talking about, I would suggest that you leave now and sign up for home economics. And I look around and for the first time I discover I'm the only girl in the room. I would not move

I did very well in college and I saw an ad. It said, Would you like a job that doesn't pay a lot of money but gives lots of satisfaction to you in terms of what you're doing in the society? And I said, They're talking to me.

It turns out to be the International Ladies Garment Workers' Union. So I went to California and doing work organizing. The status of the women in the union was very simple. They did certain kinds of jobs and the men did the other jobs. And it turned out that the jobs that the women did got paid less and the ones that the men did got paid more.

And laws were being passed. President Kennedy today signed a bill making it illegal to pay a woman less than a man for an assane job. It was a huge big deal. Discrimination against women is now to be illegal too.

Stewardesses filed a complaint of discrimination. They couldn't be married and stay on the airlines. They couldn't gain any weight when they were no longer beautiful in the eyes of the people. They were gone. Women started filing in large numbers. Newspapers had ads, help wanted male,

help wanted female. And we needed to do something about it. Some of our commissioners were not taking action because essentially they were dealing with the race issues that they were familiar with. They were not familiar with the discrimination against women. It was totally frustrating.

And so they go up to Betty Verdan's room and they agreed that the women need to rise up and say something or if nothing is going to occur. And the group grew a little bit. It started with about five at lunch, it got to fifteen or so at at in the evening, and there was agreement that in October they would have a national conference and create a new organization. Betty Fridan came up with the name National Organization for Women. The Now people asked me to join.

was getting off the train as we got ready. It turned out no, that was not the issue that if you wanted to go up to Howard University, no no taxi driver who was white was going to take you.

Well, this is not going to sound like very ladylike. And what my mother did was she took me by the hand. She took me down to the person who had come up with this idea of having a petition. And she walked right in and into the kitchen and she said to him, What m what made you decide that you should have us not living in this neighborhood? Who are you to make that decision?

So part of it I learned very quickly that if you've got an issue, you'd better start speaking up very early on it. What was nice about the end of it was the the uh principal at the school called all of the people together and told them that if they tried to get us out of the out of the neighborhood, he would make sure that we could go into his house and we could still stay there.

Well, actually, I became involved with the International Ladies Garment Workers Union because I was sitting in the library at NYU, the New York University, doing a paper, and I got bored, so I said I need a little time off. And I went down and I saw there was a magazine on the table, and the magazine said Aha You comin' down and read me and I went down and read them and they had a little ad in there. So I read that, I left New York University and I uh went down because it said at the end of it, just fill out this and let us know. And I went down and they were setting up a whole year of training for anybody who wanted to work for the union. And I of course, being in New York, went to California because it was a long distance away and I wanted to see California.

Marvelous. Sh she was f she was fantastic. I was in love with her and her husband already because I used to wave at them when I was in elementary school as the he was the governor before he was the uh president.

Very interesting to say the least. That was not unusual. There were not too many women in any place in Washington in those days or in men most of the other organizations either. And it was there I had an opportunity to speak about what was not happening with the new law that had just been passed. And as a result of that, everybody got angry and decided we needed to have something that would change that.

Well, I certainly am ha I'm happy with the progress, but I don't think by any means that we are finished. SUBJ_0006_5_to_10_years_patient_speech_p.text: I think there were two big issues. One was what was going on in the body politic, and I think we were beginning to see from the opinion polls that an outright victory for Mr. Cameron and the Conservatives was going to be very difficult. It had always been that simply because of the huge majorities that Mr. Blair had built up before before Gordon Brown took over. So there was something going on out there that was going to make the election of 2010 the more interesting. And I think that there was within that a growing sense in the electorate that they weren't simply going to take an old-fashioned campaign and leaders standing there and just handing out edicts, as it were. They wanted something different, something fresher. And the second thing was that when the debates were agreed, which I think in some respects were a reflection of that, that the leaders themselves knew they had to get out there and drill deeper down into the mindset of the electorate, was this enormous responsibility that the BBC, ourselves, and Sky would have, because it was always going to have to be the three, there was no doubt about that. The fact that we went first was literally the luck of the draw, they drew out numbers. And so that just added to the responsibility. So yeah, you're absolutely right in the question. One, something very different and interesting was going on out there, and secondly, suddenly we had this crucial role to play within it.

Curiously enough, the responsibility was awesome, and just getting it right and not getting tongue-tied and not screwing up the rules of engagement were the toughest challenges. So journalistically, the challenge was fairly modest because the questions were written by members of the public, the questions were asked by members of the public, the rules precluded my saying, well, hang on a minute, that's not what you said back in 2008. I wasn't allowed to do that. It would have been quite fun to do it, but that was not the nature of the debate. The debate was simply to enable ordinary people to put ordinary questions, which I thought on reflection were very, very good questions. We selected the ten from about 200. So there was a journalistic influence at that point, but I think it was a fairly intelligent and balanced selection of questions. My biggest challenges were all logistical. It was to make sure that these three big figures, um, all of whom I knew and all of whom I respected, uh but you know, they were one was a outgoing Prime Minister and was still Prime Minister until he lost or won the election. The other two were the two who wanted to be Prime Minister, as it were. So they're big beasts to be dealing with. Um and I had to keep them rigidly to one minute first time, one minute second time, and then four and a half, five minutes when it was open debate. And within that open debate, I also had to rigidly balance it so we didn't get too much of Cameron or too much of Clegg or not enough of Brown. So it was a kind of timekeeping ringmaster job rather than a journalistic one. But but that's quite an awesome challenge. I think it is 99% certain that we will have debates again before the 2015 election.

Five years, ten years. But again, you know, we need a lot of policemen at the moment. That was two years ago. It'd be much more difficult if you came out now. As far as journalism is concerned, here's the real dilemma. The real dilemma is we are overproducing

And you are up against the likes of Goldsmiths and Ravensbourne and Bournemouth and Portsmouth. It's a tough old world. And I'll give you an example. On the technical side here, if we've got a job applicant who got his or her qualification from Ravensbourne, we go, Oh yeah, all right, yeah, we know them. And that's because of experience. What you really need to do is get yourself into a position whereby when you say,

graduate, yeah, where where from is that? From Winchester. Oh yeah, all right, okay, fine, cool. And I don't know whether that's the case or not, but but it's all about distinctiveness. And the second part of the answer is yeah, it is tough.

you asked me earlier on about what the typical news gathering team was. Now, quite often a cameraman will go out on his or her own,
You've got a lot of journalists who your friend here, your colleague standing behind the camera, would be the interviewer as well. He'd set the shot up.

Nowadays your colleague who's standing behind the camera is quite likely to set the camera up with the shot that he wants and then come round and sit where you're sitting and conduct the interview. And then go back and edit it here on a desktop. So it's shrink, shrink, shrink. So you've got to be incredibly good as an individual. But you've also got to make sure that that university or college or whatever it might be, that

very shortly you'll be having to pay between seven and nine thousand pounds a year for the right to go to it and qualify is the best in the business. That's the real challenge. Because the best will always be employed, whether it's here or the BBC or CNN or Sky. The best will always get a job, but it's fewer, it's narrowing. And that's the real challenge

And and and that's so kind of you to say that, and I do hope that's how people feel, because my two consultants, I have a I have a uh a cardio consultant to try and figure out why the blood pressure is so high, uh, because that's what causes these little strokes in most cases. And then I have a stroke consultant who's working with me on how to ameliorate uh the condition. Both of them said to my wife, who comes to all of my appointments, you know, it's it's really weird because we know exactly who you are and we've kind of grown up with you. So very, very short-term memory is tricky. Motor skills definitely tricky. One of the things, fortunately, which if you read all the literature on it, uh, it talks about spatial awareness. So things like I remember thinking spatial awareness. I was worried that when the floor manager, brilliant, another Camilla, brought me in, you know, make sure you don't trip over. Well, uh, if Lavrov can trip up on his way to go and meet Moody, uh, and Biden can trip up on the way down about, yeah. I'm in good company if that happens. But I haven't had that spatial awareness problem at all. One weird thing is old-fashioned clocks. So if I glance down at a digital clock, that's not a problem. Um, but if I glance down at this one, old-fashioned analog one, or the big one in the kitchen at home, it sometimes takes me a while. Or if I I'm not allowed to set it anymore because I always get it wrong. Uh, and that digital clocks are brilliant, and that that's much better. So that's a perception thing that w whatever little bit of my brain looks at and says, right, if the big hand's there and the little one's there, it's eight o'clock or whatever. That's obviously had a stroke at some stage.

Um, and uh uh being married to someone who suddenly develops dementia uh is a hell of a challenge.

That was uh first of all the circular microwave millimetric waveguide. Uh so I was working s at at the starting point of nineteen sixty on circular waveguide and its related uh activities.

I really joined when STL was already thinking about optical communications because by 1959 a laser was invented and everybody got excited. But at STL Reeves recognized that the optical frequency as a carrier wave should be exploited as early as possible. So he started the work of using optical signal generated by a hollowed cathode tube, which has a very small spot, very bright spot of light generated as a plasma. There are grandparents at my signings, there are parents, there are little children. They all love sound of music.

I had thought it might be nice to write a book and I had made some notes, but I never did. My mother always wanted to write a book. We're in the process right now of writing a second book, a companion book called Letters to Lisa. I have received some beautiful letters from my book of people's experiences with the sound of music and uh the happiness it has brought them. That was the first time I'd ever realized, goodness, how this can affect

He loved Liesl in the Sound of Music. The builder that was doing his home, I had done a home with the year before, and the builder suggested he meet me. And I met with him and all he talked about was Liesl. When he called to hire me, he said, What's your favorite song from Sound of Music? And we started having this conversation. And then he started singing to me all his favorite songs from Sound and Music. And this went on easily 15 minutes, this phone conversation of him singing and me singing and doing duets. And um he finally said, Well, do you think you'd have time to decorate my house? And I said, I can certainly find the time to decorate your house. I was like a groupie and it was a very fascinating part of my life.

Yes. I had never met the Von Trapps other than Maria. I met Maria when we were filming Sound of Music in Salzburg, but very, very briefly. But three years ago we were honored by the city of Salzburg, and I helped coordinate the event by getting the seven children together with the remaining von Trapps. And I I immediately, as soon as I met them, I mean, it was just like this is this is part of my family. I became very friendly with Maria and Agatha and um The rest of the family and went to Stowe Vermont. But when I was in Stowe, I learned a lot about the real history of the Von Traps. The father never was mean. He always allowed singing in the house. And Maria the governess came only to take care of one of the children whose name happened to be Maria also because she was ill. She never came to take care of all of the children. And they loved their mother desperately, these seven children, and missed her her terribly. And it was very hard for them when their father remarried. And um then the captain and Maria, when they remarried, had three more children. So there were ten altogether. And the first child was a boy. And they used to make fun of him all the time after Sound and Music came out, saying that he should bow and say his name was Liesl. That he should no longer be Rupert, he should be Liesl. But Agatha, who is the oldest daughter, she and I are now email buddies. And then Maria, who was the daughter that the governess Maria came to take care of, she and I are good friends, we call back and forth and um and then Werner, who was Kurt's character, is still alive. But there's just the three of them from the original seven.

SUBJ_0055_5_years_patient_speech_part_00.text: When I heard a story in NPR about our troops in Afghanistan and Iraq, and they said they're there for for about uh six months, and the Department of Defense brings them back for two weeks, what they call RR, rest and recuperation with their family. Then they go back and they finish their year. The next part of the story I heard I couldn't believe they said the Department of Defense is bringing them back to the East Coast, putting them down in Baltimore, Atlanta, and they're told from here, you pay your own way home, and by the way, be back in two weeks, and we can get you back to Iraq. I didn't believe it, and I had my staff check, and it was true. I filed a bill about two weeks later to require the Department of Defense to pay the domestic travel. And every time I file a new bill, I do what's called a dear colleague letter. And within 10 days, two weeks, I had 138 co-sponsors, Republicans and Democrats, signed on this bill. And I wrote a note across the top of my dear colleague letter in blue pen and said, Dear Mr. President, I know you care about our troops, please make this happen to this morning. I said, Stuck in my pocket, and we went over to the White House Christmas party, and I saw a guy named Don Rumsfeld, and I walked over to him and I said, Mr. Secretary Dennis Warren, talk for a minute. And I reached in my pocket and handed him this letter and he said, What is this? And I told him, he said, I said, I would really appreciate it if you could help me get this done for our troops. And he said, Let me see what I can do and I'll get back with you. He never called me back, never wrote me back, but two weeks after I talked to him, he incorporated my bill into the Defense Department budget retroacted in September 1101, just like I'd written, it's now law. And that really felt good. And I I had two, in fact, back home, two uh members of the Army come up to me and thank me for doing the bill, and they said, you know, I didn't even come back from Iraq because I knew we didn't have the money to get home. This is before my bill became law. And they stayed in Iraq. And that's just horrible that we would do something like that to our people.

And one thing you don't ever want to do is you walk up to one if you see them in the wild there, because they have that front kick there, and well, you're gone.

But I love the kangaroos are beautiful. Everybody, you know, for some reason people just love the kangaroo. Well this one's still a baby, eight months old. But it's so it's not in mom's pouch anymore. No, no. They'll jump in and out of that pouch when they get like this big. All of a sudden though, what I saw once, one of them tried to jump back in the pouch this big and the mother was trying to say no. And it got hung up like this and was hanging out for about two or three hours. The mother was hopping around and she was flopping out everywhere. SUBJ_0092_5_to_10_years_patient_speech_p.text: Well, real quickly, if I could say one thing, ten seconds. The Hannah family, the Columbus Zoo, Cincinnati Zoo, and the Zoo World, this is obviously a a terrible tragedy. But however, we have given over tens of millions of dollars over the last years to the gorilla world, both lowland and mountain gorillas. I happen to have a home three miles from where the gorillas live in Rwanda. That's the mountain gorillas. However, what you see here, you hear the screaming going on, I hear it in my ear right now. You hear the screaming going on. Watch that gorilla's response, by the way. He doesn't know what's going on. This is a silverback, by the way, not a female. He hears a response, you can see from the face and the mouth, he's alarmed. Yes, he goes over and looks at the little child there. There's no doubt about that. What happens when you tranquilize the animal? Whether it's a gorilla, whatever animal it might be. As I do research in the wild with gorillas, I've seen what happens. So I know what happens. When that dart hits the animal. This animal you can imagine the animal's it's not it's like a shot, but he jumps like this. So what would happen if he had a hold of that little boy? I've seen a silverback gorilla take a green coconut, which you can't even bust up with a hatchet, and go like this. Beyond the strength of anything you would ever know. So what choice was to be you have human life and animal life. So what choice was made?

I agree one thousand percent because why? I've worked with gorillas and seen them for over thirty-five years. I have a home next to them in the in Rwanda, the mountain gorilla. These are lowland gorillas in the Congo, which I just filmed in Gabon in Africa. So when I've seen all this on my entire life of 35 years, both the zoological situation and the ones in the wild, what's happening in the wild right now is sometimes tragic. I've seen gorillas with snares on them, their hands rotting off. We try and provide millions to protect the gorillas. The point is, this animal, they made the correct decision. As a matter of fact, it's a millisecond decision. They cannot tranquilize it. It takes five to ten minutes. All of us are sorry. We we're all in the zoo world heartfelt for this whole thing. But thank goodness a human being is alive today because of the decision the Cincinnati Zoo made. So you have human life and animal life. What happened, how the child got in there is not my business. But we just can't build fifteen foot walls around everything we have in the zoological park. If you take our safety by the way, and you measure it against other other recreational things in this country, we'd be at the very top of safety. When you take the amount of uh either tragedy we've had or injuries, we're at the very top of of that not happening with the billions of visitors.

Well, for me it is with with children. You always have to watch children in a shopping center. You watch them at a water park. We have, you know, we w we do the best we can again, but advice to parents. The zoo is one of the safest places, folks, you can go in the entire world to visit a zoological park. And I'll put that up against anything. It's one of the safest places in the entire world to go. Just watch your kids. We have we have children in most zoos, three years up to 12 years old, that come to our summer camps. We have uh several hundred of them that come to our summer camps and see the zoo. But we're monitoring the kids all the time. Every every second we monitor children. And I'm sure that w that the mother here did the best she could. I guess maybe she was doing something else. I don't know. I wasn't there.

SUBJ_0093_5_years_patient_speech_part_00.text: When you cut down a forest, it doesn't Instantly look like Stanley Park. The best you can hope for is quick reforestation, such as being done on Lyle Island. And I'm standing on top of a tree which is nearly twelve feet across, stood 200 feet, and if it hadn't been brought down sometime, it would have fallen down. It was an old spruce. But don't kid yourself that when you cut down 100 acres, 100 hectares you see behind me, that you can make it, as I said, like Stanley Park.

Little did I know that in the eyes of the environmentalists, far less the Haida Indians, how much they opposed and objected to my practical application of what I regard as common sense. British Columbia lives by logging. The Indian land claims didn't come into my mind at all. After that, of course, there were a number of arrests. The Haida moved into action, and David Suzuki has been the principal campaigner against logging in Lyle Island.

In September 1985, I had the goal to stand on the top of an ancient spruce tree which had been cut down and advocate that the social credit government get off its duff and reissue logging permits for the men whose jobs were threatened at that time by their indecision. Little did I know what I was getting into. You know what happened after that with the hiders, etc. Today I am honored, and I mean honored, by the presence here of the man whom I've been hating at long distance for some time, the David Suzuki. David, surely to God there's room for both logging and the irreplaceable environment on parts of South Moresby, this jewel and our crime and our crown on the Pacific coast. No, I'm talking we're talking now about British Columbia as a whole. Within British Columbia, there is no question, logging is and will always remain an important part of our economy. However much we go for high technology and all that stuff, natural resources will always be an important part of our economy. The question is are there any pristine areas? Areas that might be left aside intact as a hedge against our ignorance? Do you think we know everything? Do you think we know enough to be able to manage our resources and replace the likes of what we're cutting down? Do you really think that? I think we have known enough to realize, said he, putting on his redneck hat, that the prosperity of British Columbia, and we'll all blame the companies for how they did it, where they did it, and when they did it, has depended almost entirely on the logging and lumber industry. This is 1987 Jack. Without it, even those parts that people want to take away from Lyle Island, we're going to be in a an even lower, more miserable winter of our discontent. Oh come on. The amount of logging that this represents is a minuscule part of the total loggable area of British Columbia. We're talking you're acting as if this little area, which represents what? 65 jobs? Is that what it represents? That's all it represents at the moment. And How many jobs are there in logging all across the province? across the province in logging and lumbering, there's about 25,000 jobs. What is all what is this is a minuscule number of jobs?

if that's true, what I my reaction would be, let's save that too. Well no, that includes the South Pole. Do you know at one time the federal government wanted to save all of the Queen Charlots? All of the Queen Charlots is a national park. Well, they've been too late for that. That's right. All we're left with now is fifteen percent of the Queen Charlotte's. And you want all of that or most of that. No, I'm saying that the only battle I'm fighting at the moment is that you cannot say that, with the exception of the Windy Bay Ecological Reserve, that Lyle Island is a jewel in our crown. That Lyle Island, Windy Bay is a part of that. That's right. Windy Bay is saved. Lyle Island has been logged for 40 to 70 years. Much of it is natural regeneration.
A lot of it is gone. Why the fuss about Lyle Island? Why not leave f 15 years of logging for a hundred men to keep Sandspit healthy in Lyle Island?

SUBJ_0101_after_symptoms_patient_speech_.text: A few weeks ago, my best friend for the past fifty-nine years handed me a clipping, quoting a nineteen seventy-three statement by a longtime friend of a great many of us, Senator Sam J. Irvin, Jr.

except for the fact that I am now already a few years older than Senator Irvin was when he made his decision on December 13, 1973, that he would not run for a reelection in 1974, my family has counseled me that my situation today is not materially different from what Senator Irvin said in 1973.

and without hesitation and without fail. These young people, we call ourselves the Helm Senate family, by the way, these young people often work around the clock, and many times they have worked through the weekends to help people who needed a helping hand.
And many citizens from other states who brought their problems to us were served promptly with genuine interest in making certain that the problems were solved if at all possible.

As early members of our Senate family have moved on to responsibilities with other branches of the government or with businesses or educational institutions, new young people were eager to join in our efforts to serve the citizens of our state.

And today their careers are all over the landscape. Federal judges and teachers and business leaders and bankers, and some have gone on to theological schools, and now some are top advisors to the present president of the United States, George Bush.
God helps and I have thanked the Lord countless times for those remarkable young people and women, young men and women.

I have often shared a commitment with young people, a commitment that I made to myself on election night, 1972. And my commitment that night was that I would never, ever fail to meet with a young person or a group of young people who wanted to see me. Now that 1972 campaign enabled me to meet personally hundreds of young men and women whom otherwise I would never have met.

And having been the beneficiary of more than 100,000, 100,000 young visitors during the past 29 years, I can assure you that the future leadership of this state and our nation is in good hands. And third and last, but certainly not least. There's no way I can adequately express my gratitude to the thousands of people who pitched in and gave their support and prayers in all five of my elections to the United States Senate.
Now, all of this is a long way of saying that I'm not running again, and that I thank you most sincerely from the bottom of my heart for letting me have my say.
I have just confirmed speculation that I will not seek reelection next year.

I am by no means announcing my retirement because a great deal of work lies ahead of the United States Senate this fall and next year when there will be much significant legislation. For example, The Senate will be taking up and renewing the Farm Bill, which comes around just about every five years. And you don't need me to explain to you how important this particular farm bill will be to the farm families all across North Carolina.

In addition, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, yes, I'm not no longer the chairman, but the Senate Foreign Relations Committee will consider, among other important matters, significant legislation that will set the course for the future of America's defense system.

And then there's the necessity of monitoring the implementation of the Helms Biden demands of reforming the United Nations, which, by the way, has already saved the American taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.

left to Dot Helms and me, we want to enjoy more time with our children and grandchildren, and we will do that. And needless to say, Dot and I intend, the Lord willing. To be more actively involved in trying to be helpful to that remarkable foundation down at Wingate.
Now, I don't know precisely how to say this, but Dot and I hope that one way or another we can continue, as private citizens, to be helpful to the great people of North Carolina.
One thing is for sure we will never forget you, and we shall always be grateful for all that you have meant to us.

SUBJ_0213_after_symptoms_patient_speech_.text: What has changed the most? Satellites would be the first thing that I would say, because, you know, we have an awful lot of people, and this started years ago. It's not just me, but this started years ago where people liked to watch the games on television and listen to them on the radio. Carolina, when I was in the late 1950s during the run, the perfect run by the 57 team, a 32-0, WNC-TV was asked to start putting some of those games on the air. Well, the first one they put on the air, they didn't put it on the air, but they put it on the air. And they had audio with it, play-by-play audio. And the radio stations, there were no set networks back in those days. There were a lot of radio stations that went around and broadcasted an assortment of college basketball games. They'd be in Chapel Hill, say, on a Wednesday night, and on Thursday night they might be in Raleigh. Saturday night they might be in Durham or Old Wake Forest, where the Deacons were playing at that time before they moved to Winston-Salem. And so there were a lot of people, and all those radio stations, they really got mad. And I can tell you, you know, I've been to a lot of those radio stations, and I can understand why, because here was public television, the state-owned educational station on the campus of the University of North Carolina, coming in and taking audience away from them. So they had a quick meeting, and they allowed as to how WNC-TV would televise other games, but they would only televise the video, and they would put natural sound behind it. And they would run streamers across the bottom of the screen telling people to get the audio. They had to tune into the audio. They had to tune into their favorite radio station carrying the game. And so that worked very, very well for everybody concerned. And they called it broad vision. And so when satellites came along, people would still like to do that because they felt like we had a better feel and knew more about, say, the Tar Heels than television announcers did coming in and just, you know, being here less than a day and then trying to do the game. And so they wanted to hear the games while they watched them. Well, satellites made that difficult to do because a lot of times the radio audio, because we had only one satellite jump, was getting there well ahead of the television picture, which had two and sometimes three satellite jumps. And so satellite is the big change. And then, of course, before that, it was, you know, videotape. And now there's hardly any place we can go that we can't do things with wireless microphones and that sort of thing. So the electronic end of the business has really been in the big change through all these years. Yeah. Do you think you could have imagined any of this stuff when you started? I don't think so, particularly not the satellites, you know. And now to see high definition and they need two tractor trailer units to come in to give you high definition. But high definition is probably going to have the greatest impact on televised sports than anything else because it really does. I mean, you've talked about before being in the game. That's what high definition does. High definition really puts you in the game. And as long as professional teams and college teams, for that matter, see fit to keep raising ticket prices, I'm concerned about what the impact on what the revenue that particularly college teams need to generate. For example, at Carolina, football and basketball needs to generate a lot of revenue because they are basically supporting 26 other varsity teams.
But high definition really does put you into the game. And it'll be interesting to see what impact that has over the next few years.

SUBJ_0026_age_above_70_patient_speech_pa.text: When I received the Nobel Prize for Literature, I got to wondering exactly how my songs related to literature. I wanted to reflect on it and see where the connection was. I'm going to try to articulate that to you, and most likely it will go in a roundabout way, but I hope what I say will be worthwhile and purposeful. If I was to go back to the dawning of it all, I guess I'd have to start with Buddy Holly. Buddy died when I was about 18 and he was 22. From the moment I first heard him, I felt akin. I felt related, like he was an older brother. I even thought I resembled him. Buddy played the music that I loved, the music I grew up on, country western, rock and roll, and rhythm and blues. Three separate strands of music that he intertwined and infused into one genre,

Then out of the blue, the most uncanny thing happened. He looked me right straight dead in the eye, and he transmitted something, something I didn't know what, and he gave me the chills. I think it was a day or two after that that his plane went down, and I was in the car, and I was down, and somebody, somebody I'd never seen before, handed me a Leadbelly record with the song Cottonfields on it, and that record changed my life right then and there, transported me into a world I'd never known. It was like an explosion went off, like I'd been walking in darkness, and all of a sudden the darkness was illuminated. It was like somebody laid hands on me. I must have played that record a hundred times. It was on a label I'd never heard of,

I knew the rhetoric. None of it went over my head. The devices, the techniques, the secrets, the mysteries, and I knew all the deserted roads that it traveled on to. I could make it all connect and move with the current of the day. When I started writing my own songs, the folk lingo was the only vocabulary that I knew, and I used it. But I had something else as well. I had principles and sensibilities and an informed view of the world, and I had had that for a while. Learned it all in grammar school. Don Quixote, Ivanhoe, Robinson Crusoe, Gulliver's Travels, Tales of Two Cities, all the rest. Typical grammar school reading that gave you a way of looking at life, an understanding of human nature, and a standard to measure things by. I took all that with me when I started composing lyrics, and the themes from those books worked their way into many of my songs, either knowingly or unintentionally. I wanted to write songs unlike anything anybody ever heard, and these themes were fundamental. Specific books that have stuck with me ever since I read them way back in grammar school. I want to tell you about three of them. Moby Dick, All Quiet on the Western Front, and The Odyssey. Moby Dick is a fascinating book, a book that's filled with scenes of high drama and dramatic dialogue. The book makes demands on you. The plot is straightforward. The mysterious Captain Ahab, captain of a ship called the Pequod, an egomaniac with the peg leg, pursuing his nemesis, the great white whale Moby Dick, who took his leg, and he pursues him all the way from the Atlantic, around the tip of Africa, and into the Indian Ocean. He pursues the way around both sides of the earth. It's an abstract goal, nothing concrete or definite. He calls Moby the Emperor, sees him as the embodiment of evil. Ahab's got a wife and child back in Nantucket that he reminisces about now and again. You can anticipate what will happen. The ship's crew is made up of men of different races, and any one of them who sights the whale will be given the reward of a gold coin. A lot of zodiac symbols, religious allegory, stereotypes. Ahab encounters other waving vessels, presses the captain for details about Moby. Have they seen him? There's a crazy prophet, Gabriel, on one of the vessels, and he predicts Ahab's doom. Says Moby is the incarnate of a Shaker God, and that any dealings with him will lead to disaster. He says that to Captain Ahab. Another ship's captain, Captain Boomer, he lost an arm to Moby, but he tolerates that and he's happy to have survived. He can't accept Ahab's lust for vengeance. This book tells how different men react in different ways to the same experience.
None of it hardly rational. Highbrow. Lowbrow. Chasing illusion. Chasing death. The great white whale. White as a polar bear. White as a white man. The emperor. The nemesis. The embodiment of

I liked the idea, the idea that a guy had gone undercover and he was trying to find a homosexual killer by pretending to be a homosexual and getting picked up cruising. So I had a kind of visual idea about that. Then there was the frustrated housewife and the psychiatrist who was born in the wrong body and is threatened by the fact that he's aroused by his patient and he's making a male-to-female transition and the fact that he becomes aroused brings out the murderer in him.

But this concept of being in the wrong body, it's almost like a Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde idea, at least the way I was looking at it. So I had all these ideas sort of going around, and then I had the science fair winner myself running around, the kid that's solving the crime. SUBJ_0049_age_above_70_patient_speech_pa.text: We had a panel here. I was talking with Spike Lee and some other colleagues in cinema about the nostalgia there is for the old days of cinema where you would have a community worshipping in the church of cinema and a communal experience, maybe partly religious. I think Alma Dover talked about the sacredness of the cinema and I said that you must perhaps be a Catholic in order to believe that.

I think cinema has been permanently disrupted. I think it will never be. It will never be the same. And I think it might be like vinyl records, perhaps, or people who still type on typewriters. It will be a retro activity, going to a cinema. I mean, there are social reasons why people like to go out to a cinema, but for me, I haven't gone to the cinema for many, many years, I have to confess.

because in the actual making of it, it is cinema, but in the releasing of it, it seems to be something else that it is not shown on big screens. It's shown on your iPhone, your Apple Watch. Maybe I've said, I wouldn't mind seeing Lawrence of Arabia on an Apple Watch. I think that would be good. I think it would be a different movie, but it would be interesting. So I think Netflix is the example that is the most disruption. It's unprecedented. If you make a movie for Netflix, it might never be seen on a cinema screen, but in one day, it will be released in 190 countries. This has never happened before. This is really quite incredible.
As a child, I would go every Saturday to a theater called the Pylon on College Street. And in those days, people were not worried about their children being kidnapped and murdered.

So there would be a stream of children You know, Lemmings, you know, coming from all of the streets down to College Street, a big street, and going to the cinema, the Pylon, where we would watch cartoons, and we would watch cowboy movies, you know, Hopalong Cassidy, Roy Rogers, pirate movies maybe, kids, you know, good action kids' movies and stuff. And then one day, I came out of the Pylon and across the street, because where I was living had become an Italian cinema, it was the Italian section of Toronto.

and I saw people coming out of the studio across the street. There were no children, it was all adults, and they were all weeping, they were crying. And I was shocked, because I thought, what movie could do that to grown-up people, to make them sobbing on the street together? So I crossed the street, and I looked at the poster for the film, and it was La Strada from Fellini. And of course, many years later, I was also watching La Strada, I was also weeping,

Of course, like anything, any other technology, you can overuse it.

have human characteristics. I've, for me, technology is just an extension of our bodies and our brains, and that means that the technology will be both wonderful and horrific at the same time. SUBJ_0084_age_less_than_55_patient_speec.text: What happened was I moved to a new school, and I was about 12 years old, and there was already a well-formed society in that school. And because I was the outsider and didn't fit in, the school sport became throwing me off the edge of the parking lot, down a 20-foot bank every recess. And I don't really remember how it started, but I know that my reaction was just to pick myself, dust myself off, and crawl up to the top again. And I developed great sympathy from the girls. So while I was getting thrown off the hill at recess, I was gaining a benefit that lasted through the rest of the day.

Then I became involved, after that fear dissipated, in the other processes that made acting interesting to me. The interest in storytelling and the effect that was created between myself and the audience, that began to help me find a place in society that I hadn't felt before.

I never really did do well in television. I survived from... from small part to small part. But my ambition was always to do the kind of work, to play the kinds of roles that didn't seem to occur very often in television, especially not episodic television. And episodic television, I should say, has come a long way since the days when I was doing Love, American Style. Oh, wow.

What I was anxious to do was to play with the big boys. I wanted to do ambitious kinds of films. I wanted to take on characters that were a bit more complicated and interesting. I didn't kill my wife! I don't care! And I was aware of the fact that if I stayed at the same place doing episodic television over and over again, I would wear out my face. I mean, I don't want to wind up like that. I never get a chance to do the kind of work I wanted to do.

And because I discovered another way of putting food on the table for my young family by doing carpentry, I was able to wait it out. Because I always knew that tenacity was more important than almost anything else. I arrived in Hollywood with the metaphoric bus with a group of young people who all had a similar ambition to mine. And as the years went by, the attrition rate eliminated many of those people from the competition pool.

And finally, there was only a few of us left from that entering class. And I always saw life that way, that you really had to stick it out to prevail. And along the way, of course, I learned a great deal more about my craft than I knew when I first started. Well, I was 35 when I first did something. David Hargreaves and I, two little gay boys in Bolton and neither of us knew it of the

It's a nonsense. It's laughable. And then she said, well, you know, many young men and women are confused about their sexuality, and they seek help from professional psychiatrists to help them through. And it became absolutely stuck. I don't think I really thought about it very much. I think I was so overwhelmed and so carried away with myself... At working at all. At working at all, yes, that I was sort of really rather grateful for that.

I don't know. I think you have to be a screen actress. I really don't think I am. I think you have to have a completely different outlook. You know, by the time I get on the floor after two and a half hours of makeup, I find it impossible. And also the lack of contact, the fact that there isn't an audience, the fact that it's all a question of how you look. People are always, always worried, always around you all the time trying to make you look like this, your costume isn't right. I don't know, I found by the end of the day that one's morale was so low that maybe the camera is so close that you feel you can't do anything because it will look ugly. You know, you get so concerned with the fact that you're in the wrong light. Or if you do that, it's unattractive on the camera and you mustn't do this. You get so inhibited, at least I do, that I tend not to do anything. I always feel that I'm, you know, I'm fine in a film if I'm acting a neurotic person or a small, tight, you know, shy person. That's not quite so difficult.

I suppose it must be true. I don't know why. Perhaps it's because, you know, when things go well, it is a bit alarming. I sometimes think that I've had so much luck and so much good fortune that it frightens me somehow. I always feel there's got to be something.

Well, it was then, I must say, because that was a long run. Believe me, when you're in a long run, you want to get out and see as much as you can, and relax. At the moment, and working in the way I do at the moment, I very rarely have that time. One rehearses during the day, plays at night, and if you go on tour, it's not all that easy.

And I immediately went to the Oxford Playhouse, where indeed I got a job, which was for two weeks, to be in The Happiest Days of Your Life, to play the Scots girl, you know, Elizabeth Cahoon. And this was immediately trodden on and I wasn't allowed to do it. So then I decided to go to drama school. I mean, I'd made up my mind to do that anyway before I left school. When I was at the Playhouse, I used to work in university productions because they did an awful lot of them there and they did lots of cabarets and reviews and they were all sort of run by Ned Sheeran, Desmond O'Donovan, people like that. And I did those endlessly.
And, you know, if you were bright enough at Oxford, you could almost do weekly rep round the colleges. You could get enough productions to do a term to keep you very busy.

SUBJ_0128_age_55_to_70_patient_speech_pa.text: It was really, yeah, earlier. Much earlier, I think. And it had to do with growing up downtown in the Lower East Side. It had to do with Elizabeth Street, Mott Street, Mulberry Street, and St. Patrick's Old Cathedral.

You know, and seeing that church and the graveyard and the red brick wall that's still there, still around it. And when I was about eight or nine years old, I heard these stories about these groups of people called the Know-Nothings who wanted to attack the church at one point in time in the 19th century, and that the Irish-American community gathered around the church, not just the men, but the women and the children, too, and the groups of Know-Nothings who came down from the Bowery.

Were stopped by that and turned away. And I was surprised to hear that story because eight or nine, I thought everybody, there was no problem coming to America, that when immigrants came in, everybody just assimilated. There was no, you know, what was the problem? I was surprised to hear about the anger and the rage against Catholicism and the Irish at that time. And so I started doing a lot of finding these old books from the period about St. Patrick's Old Cathedral. And researching, and then I found the book Gangs of New York.
Well, that really made it very clear in my mind that there was a whole section in a sense of,

That was not really taught to many of us at school. I think we always thought about the Civil War, that there was the North and the South. I mean, elementary schools, not later, but especially, I'm talking about an education, an elementary school in the 1950s. The North and the South, there was a very sharp dividing line. Everybody above that line was for the Union, everybody below was for the Confederacy.

And in the South, certainly in the mountains of North Carolina and Tennessee, lots of people were for the North. And when I read the Gangs of New York, the Herbert Asbury book, the richness of the life of the underworld in New York at that time, particularly the place of the Five Points, which was termed the worst slum in the world at the time, in the 1850s. In fact, I think you know, Charles Dickens came here, wrote a book called American Notes, and on his tour...
I felt I wanted to create that world that nobody's really ever seen before in film, kind of a world that, in a sense, the foundation from all, I guess, all my other movies came from, I think.

SUBJ_0128_age_above_70_patient_speech_pa.text: Well, I think certainly those questions are there. I mean, as you know, I had read the book. I had read the book back in 1988, and for all those years, to try to come to grips, I should say, with translating it to a visual form, a film, you know, took many years, until about 2006 to be able to work on the script properly with my friend Jay Cox. But throughout that time, all these questions did come to mind. That's the point, I think, about ultimately what is the essential?
How does one, without doing damage to the culture that you're bringing these ideas to, how does one help, in a way, other cultures, other people, other ways of life, other ways of thinking?

So that what I mean is that I think ultimately it has to be the very behavior of those calling themselves Christians. It has to be the behavior, I think. It has to be the essential Christianity in the person who is expectant. It has to be the way of sounding this, I think, and it's got to be in behavior, and I think ultimately people say, well, I'd like to, when somebody grows up and says, I'd like to be like that person was to others, which is compassionate, service, and humility. Now, how do you do that without being an organized group that goes into a place where people are completely different culture and way of life and thinking for so many, for generations, for thousands of years? Yeah, you have to take into mind who the people are, what they believe, what they think, how they think, you know? And then find the essence and find what is similar, what is human in each other, in a way.

So, in that sense, Silence, although set in the early 17th century in Japan, is very much a contemporary movie that speaks to contemporary concerns here. How is Christianity going to adapt to a different society? In that sense, I guess it reminds me of...

So when I was about 18 years old, 17 years old, I had planned if I could ever make a movie or do something. I was constantly obsessed with it. So it was appearing in different forms and projects I was writing about for school and things like that. So the next step was a film. And so The Last Temptation came out of that because between the Pasolini and then, between that and more conventional, maybe a bad word, but traditional epic films coming out of Hollywood, even ones that took chances like King of Kings, Nick Ray, or Barabbas, which is an interesting, beautiful story, an underrated film by Richard Fleischer, did a version of it, Anthony Quinn.

One had to go against all this and had to find a new way. And I found that The Last Temptation was something that raised questions that I thought, well, we should be able to speak about as Catholics, as Christians, as people.

And it's fascinating to me. And maybe there's some aspects, certainly, of exoticism to it. But I wanted to find out more. And Melissa Matheson had written this very beautiful script. And we thought... Well, it was time to try it, to see if we can work this out and reach a kind of, I hate to use the word, but it is reaching out for transcendent experience

Because Christianity is, I'm Christian, so Catholic, so I could explore meditation or transcendence or the metaphysics of the East. I could explore it. I don't know, but I could find my way through it, maybe, with the help of the Tibetans, with the help of the Dalai Lama, with the help of Melissa Matheson, who sadly is now gone.

And maybe, you know, it's many different reasons why. I think to touch upon aspects of religion in a deeper way doesn't necessarily mean it's going to be a picture that everybody's going to, it may not be as accessible at first.

But my look, they were telling me, was Irish.

So I took the name of Martin from Robert Dale Martin. I talk about in the book was casting director at CBS when I came here, and he was encouraging to me. And the last name Sheen from Fulton J. Sheen. He was the auxiliary bishop of New York at the time, and when I was growing up as a teenager, he was the first teleSUBJ_0206t on television.
He beat Burrell, Milton Burrell in the ratings,
I mean, he had this great look, and he was very intense. I didn't have a clue what he was talking about, his theology or politics, but I loved his performance.
I worked as a theater usher. I worked as a messenger. I worked as a long-time job in Staten Island in a car wash.

And I would work under Ramon. And I had a Social Security card under that name. Every now and then I'd get a job as an actor, and it got confusing because I couldn't prove that I was that person. And so I wrote the IRS and said,

I'm starting to make some dough, and I don't have a card. So they sent me another card with that name, the same number. So I still have them. And if this gig doesn't work, I can always go back to Ramon.
